This made me take Reflections into considerac[i]on and finding them 
regular soe that the Angle of Reflection of all sorts of Rays was equal to 
their Angle of incidence. I understood that by their mediation Opticke 
instruments might be brought to any degree of perfection imaginable 
provided a Reflecting substance could be found, which I would polish 
as finely as glass and reflect as much light as glass transmits and the 
art of com[m]unicating to it a parabolick figure be also attained But 
there seemed very great difficulties and I haue almost thought them 
Insuperable, when I further considered that every irregularity in a 
Reflecting superficies makes the Rays stray 5 or 6 times more out of 
their due course then the like irregularities in a reflecting [refracting?] one Soe yt a
much greater curiosity would be here requisite then in figureing glasses 
for refraction 
Amidst these thought I was forced from Cambridge by ye Intervening 
Plague, and it was more then two yeares before I proceeded further 
But then haueing thought on a tender way of polishing proper for 
metall where by as I imagined the figure alsoe would be corrected to the 
last I began to try what might be effected in this kind and by degrees 
so farr perfected an Instrument (in the essential parts of it like that 
I sent to London) by which I could descern Iupiters 4 concomitants, and 
showed them divers times to two of my acquantances I could alsoe 
discerne the Moon=like phase of Venus but not very distinctly nor 
without some nicenesse in disposeing the Instrument 
From that time I was interrupted till this Autumn when I made 
the other, And as at that was sensible better then the first (especially for 
Day=Objects) so I doubt not but they will be still brought to a much 
greater perfection by their endeavours who as you informe me are 
takeing care about it at London 
I haue thought sometimes to make a Microscope wch in like manner 
would haue insted of an object glasse, a Reflecting peice of metall 
And this I hope they will also take into considerac[i]on for those Instru=
ments seeme as capable of improuement as Telescopes & perhaps more because 
but one reflective peice of metall is requisite in them as you may 
perceive by the annexed diagram where AB representeth the 
object metall CD

But to returne from this digression I told you that light is not 
similar or homogeneal but consists of difforme Rays some of wch are more 
refrangable then others So that of those which are a like incident on
